reporting-org.narrative: FONDS VOOR ONTWIKKELINGSSAMENWERKING - SOCIALISTISCHE SOLIDARITEIT VZW

title.narrative: PROG 2017-2021_Outcome_Organizations of people in precarious living conditions have contributed to the improvement and the enforcement of labour rights and the right to social protection, including the right to health, with attention for the interests of both men and women.

description.narrative: The programme in Mozambique focusses on ILO pillars 2 and 3 of Decent Work, i.e. on improving labour rights and the access thereto, and the right to social protection and health for the beneficiaries and members of our partners’ organisations. The beneficiaries are men and women in precarious living and working conditions, mainly agricultural workers, domestic workers and small-scale farmers who try to organize themselves to change their circumstances and to demand their rights, with a specific focus on women and youth. Our partners provide education and information on rights, on organizing and on the economic and environmental context; they build the confidence and empower their members/beneficiaries, specifically women, and stimulate them to unite in order to demand their rights. In addition to mobilizing communities and workers, our Mozambican partners will try to have an impact on decision making processes and the drafting, amending and enforcing of new and existing laws. They will do so through participating in social dialogue and collective bargaining platforms. They will support active community participation and awareness and they will try to make voices of precarious workers and communities heard in society.

title.narrative: Organizations of people in precarious living conditions have contributed to the improvement and the enforcement of labour rights and the right to social protection, including the right to health, with attention for the interests of both men and women.
Level of improvement in access to the right to social protection, including the right to health, as experienced and indicated by the target groups of the partners.

comment.narrative: Representatives of our partners’ target groups identify the following problems related to access to social protection and health: Vulnerable rural communities: - lack of knowledge in communities about health rights and lack of confidence and of equal access to state institutions to demand those rights - lack of understanding of the importance of social determinants of health, including environmental and gender related issues - lack of unity and solidarity and of organizing around health rights in vulnerable communities; lack of community participation and mobilization around health - understaffed and under-resourced public health care system; long distances to health care providers, long waiting times - lack of government support to community participation; no prioritization of equitable, fair and quality primary health care by government Specific for women: - lack of maternity care and (expectant) mother and baby accommodation in healthcare facilities; - lack of power of decision of women with regards to health care treatments for themselves and their children In relation to the social determinants of health: - high impact of climate change and contamination; poor housing conditions; lack of access to water and electricity; food insecurity; gender based violence; teenage pregnancies; violence; high prevalence of HIV/aids and other communicable diseases; low self-esteem and confidence.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 2 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.

Actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 5 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health. To begin with, trade unions in Mozambique scored a major victory when they successfully lobbied government to make changes to Labour Law, resulting in an increase of maternity leave days from 60 to 90 days. This has increased the job security of women and allowed them enough time to care for themselves and their babies before they return to work. Other important achievements include widespread adoption of occupational health and safety standards, including the provision of protective clothing to agricultural workers, training on First Aid and provision of transport for workers by employers in 13 companies in which SINTAF has a presence. Through the provision of solar equipment to 5 rural committees, members of SINTAF and their communities now have improved access to health care, given local health facilities are able to operate at night and also store perishable medicines in freezers powered by the solar panels donated and maintained by the union. With regards to community heath, FOS partner UPCG has been at the forefront of the fight for improved health and social protection. By addressing issues such as the under-resourcing of public health care facilities, access to transport for rural communities and electricity at local health facilities, UPCG has contributed to improved maternity care and decision making by women on issues to do with both their own health. Further, through its network of 30 health activists in each of the 13 districts it operates, UPCG has made it possible for communities to get immediate assistance in cases of emergency, but also organise themselves to lobby for improved health service delivery.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 3 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.

Actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 5 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.
To begin with, trade unions in Mozambique scored a major victory when they successfully lobbied government to make changes to Labour Law, resulting in an increase of maternity leave days from 60 to 90 days. This has increased the job security of women and allowed them enough time to care for themselves and their babies before they return to work.
Other important achievements include widespread adoption of occupational health and safety standards, including the provision of protective clothing to agricultural workers, training on First Aid and provision of transport for workers by employers in 13 companies in which SINTAF has a presence.
Through the provision of solar equipment to rural committees across five provinces, members of SINTAF and their communities now have improved access to health care, given local health facilities are able to operate at night and also store perishable medicines in freezers powered by the solar panels donated and maintained by the union.
With regards to community heath, FOS partner UPCG has been at the forefront of the fight for improved health and social protection. By addressing issues such as the under-resourcing of public health care facilities, access to transport for rural communities and electricity at local health facilities, UPCG has contributed to improved maternity care and decision making by women on issues to do with both their own health.
Further, through its network of 30 health activists in each of the 13 districts it operates, UPCG has made it possible for communities to get immediate assistance in cases of emergency, but also organise themselves to lobby for improved health service delivery.
Following the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, FOS partners lobbied for improved social protection for workers and their communities. This resulted in workers receiving compensation following retrenchments, workers being provided with healthcare and protective equipment, and income generating initiatives being implemented to help workers supplement their income.
Finally, SINTAF has implemented activities specifically targeting women and workers in precarious conditions.

title.narrative: Level of improvement in (access to) labour rights and reduction in labour market flexibility and informalisation as experienced and indicated by the target groups of the partners.

comment.narrative: Representatives of our partners’ target groups identify the following problems related to labour rights and labour conditions: General for all precarious workers: - lack of: knowledge on labour rights, confidence in and access to state institutions to demand rights - lack of: enforcement of existing labour laws and inspections; - no adequate access to social protection (paid maternity leave, sickness or invalidity benefits, pension, funeral cover) - historically skewed and exploitative power relations; discrimination, sexism and harassment from managers, supervisors and employers, especially toward women - No ratification of ILO C183 Specific for Agricultural Workers: - low sectoral minimum wages; non-respect of minimum wages through quota systems - decrease of permanent employment, high job insecurity, increase of flexible labour - foreign and private company owners not complying with labour laws and social dialogue - low levels of organized seasonal/casual workers; - poor working conditions in terms of health and safety; - no sectoral collective bargaining; no ratification of ILO C184 Specific for Domestic Workers: - No sectoral minimum wages – salaries differ greatly depending on the place of employment - High dependence of the worker on the employer and high vulnerability; domestic work not considered as actual work; discrimination, sexism and harassment from the employer - Isolation (single employee in private household) and lack of freedom of association - No ratification of ILO C189

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 2 problems concerning access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation.

Actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 3 problems concerning access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation:
Firstly, the work done by SINED, with its 9 000 members, has resulted in improved working conditions for domestic workers, many of whom are now able to demand things such as respect for working hours, protective clothing and healthcare from their employers. Improved working conditions include less sexual harassment and increased job security.
Secondly, SINED has implemented a campaign for the ratification of Convention 189 protecting the rights of domestic workers. Through this effort, the trade union has lobbied parliament to adopt and ratify the Convention, and in the process of doing this, increased the visibility of organised labour in general, and the plight of domestic workers in particular. This has resulted in domestic work increasingly being recognised as actual work.
SINTAF has also made great strides in ensuring increased knowledge of labour rights and other issues affecting workers such as casualisation, power relations and gender based discrimination. Training and capacity building of shop stewards and workers' committees has resulted in workers successfully fighting for their right to things such as permanent contracts, as is the case with agriculture estate, Bananalandia, which has converted 160 casual workers into permanent workers. Another example is around health and safety. Members of SINTAF now understand the obligations of the employer around protective equipment and have been able to demand this not just for members of the union, but all employees. In all, this has contributed to improved job security and a reduction in discrimination of workers.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 4 problems concerning access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation.

FOS partners contributed to improvements related to 4 problems concerning access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation:
Firstly, the work done by SINED, with its 9 000 members, has resulted in improved working conditions for domestic workers, many of whom are now able to demand things such as respect for working hours, protective clothing and healthcare from their employers. Improved working conditions include less sexual harassment and increased job security.
Domestic workers also have access to social security benefits, as a direct result of the work done SINED in informing them of their rights and assisting them with registering for social welfare.
Further, SINED has implemented a campaign for the ratification of Convention 189 protecting the rights of domestic workers. Through this effort, the trade union has lobbied parliament to adopt and ratify the Convention, and in the process of doing this, increased the visibility of organised labour in general, and the plight of domestic workers in particular. This has resulted in domestic work increasingly being recognised as actual work. C189 has also been tabled for debate in the National Assembly.
SINTAF ensured workers have increased knowledge of labour rights and other issues affecting workers such as casualisation, power relations and gender based discrimination. Training and capacity building of shop stewards and workers' committees resulted in workers successfully fighting for their right to things such as permanent contracts, as is the case with agriculture estate, Bananalandia, which has converted 160 casual workers into permanent workers. Another example is around health and safety. Members of SINTAF now understand the obligations of the employer around protective equipment and have been able to demand this not just for members of the union, but all employees. In all, this has contributed to improved job security and a reduction in discrimination of workers.
